moves.1. d4: Switch it up with a queen opening as opposed to my usual king's opening.
moves.2. Nf3: Protecting the lone pawn out and starting the castle process
moves.2... e6: he protects as well, but with a pawn.
moves.6... Nf6: i could have gone either way, i reallllly don't like bishops.
moves.7... cxd6 8. a3: a little air, and trying to break that stagnant line up
moves.8... a6 9. Bd3: castle coming, i put my man the bishop right in the middle.
moves.10... Nc6 11. Re1: future move for e6. It does pan out, and pans out big.
moves.11... Qd6 12. Bf4: how dare you bring your queen out?
moves.12... Qe7: Thats right, sucka. I contemplated bishop to f5 knowing he wouldn't do it or else lose the queen. queen and bishop isn't always a good trade for a queen, but I was willing here. Instead I found a better move, moving the knight in.
moves.13. Ne5 Nxd4: Yes, dude, it's a free pawn, but your knight is completely unprotected.
moves.14. Ng6: Attacks the queen, he probably thinks thats he getting a knight for a pawn, but he forgot about leaving that knight wide open
moves.14... fxg6 15. Bxg6+: his check forces him to move. I knew he wouldn't cover with the queen, and I knew he couldn't come closer with his king (the only way would be on the diagonal)
moves.15... Kf8: Wow, dangerous to angle your king behind a queen on a diagonal. I wish I would have had protection on d6 for the pin.
moves.16. Qxd4: I ended up  1 on the deal he thought he would be  2 on
moves.18. Qc6: Working the diagonal line on the rook.
moves.18... Ra7: Not sure, I think he thought my queen would be trapped in deeper than it really was?
moves.19. Qxc8: I don't see the trap. In hindsight, I don't believe there was one.
moves.19... Qd7: He wants to trade queen after his screw up, but.....
moves.20. Qc5+: He leaves a  very nice line open.
moves.20... Qe7: "Oh man, I really screwed up, now trade me queens??"
moves.21. Rxe6: Great move opened up, he does see it and resigns. If he went for my queen, rook to e8 would have been mate.
